'''Catfish Keith''' (born February 9, 1962)<ref name="Virgin"/> is an American [[Country blues|acoustic blues]] singer-songwriter and guitarist.  He is best known as an exponent of the [[steel guitar]].  He has released several solo [[album]]s, including 2001's ''A Fist Full of Riffs''.<ref>{{cite web|last=Nickson |first=Chris |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/a-fist-full-of-riffs-mw0000013922 |title=A Fist Full of Riffs - Catfish Keith : Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date=2001-09-25 |accessdate=2012-12-08}}</ref>

''[[The Guardian]]'' described him as "a solo revelation" who was "breaking new ground for blues.<ref name="AMG"/> Twice a [[Blues Music Award]] nominee for 'Best Acoustic Blues Album', he has had ten number one independent radio chart hit albums.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chapelarts.org/index.php?main_page=product_ticket_info&cPath=6&products_id=210 |title=Catfish Keith - £10.00 |publisher=Chapel Arts |date=2012-11-13 |accessdate=2012-12-08}}</ref>

==Early life and career==
Catfish Keith was born '''Keith Daniel Kozacik''' in [[East Chicago, Indiana|East Chicago]], [[Indiana]], and was first inspired by blues music he heard on the radio.  These included songs by [[Buddy Guy]], [[Howlin' Wolf]] and [[Muddy Waters]], although by the time he owned a guitar in his teenage years, he listened mostly to [[Son House]].  He attended high school in [[Davenport, Iowa]], before setting out across the United States and beyond learning to sing and play his brand of the blues.  He traveled to the [[Caribbean]], where his musical education benefited from hearing [[Joseph Spence (musician)|Joseph Spence]].<ref name="AMG"/>

His [[stage name]] originated from a diving partner in the [[Virgin Islands]] who, having seen his efforts at swimming, [[nickname]]d him "Catfish-Swimmin'-Around," and "Catfish-Steel-Guitar-Man."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bluesinlondon.com/interviews/int_catfish.html |title=Interview with Catfish Keith |publisher=Blues in London |date= |accessdate=2012-12-08}}</ref>  Catfish Keith had his debut album, ''Catfish Blues'' (1984), released by [[Kicking Mule Records]]. He continued to tour constantly and picked up playing tips from watching [[Jessie Mae Hemphill]], [[Henry Townsend (musician)|Henry Townsend]], [[Johnny Shines]] and [[David "Honeyboy" Edwards]].<ref name="AMG"/>

Keith married in 1988 and founded his own [[record label]], Fish Tail Records. 1991's ''Pepper in My Shoe'' sparked global interest in his work, and he toured both Europe and the United States.  He appeared on the cover pages of the publications ''Blues Life'', ''Blueprint'', ''Block'' and ''The Guardian'', and his follow-up effort, ''Jitterbug Swing'' was nominated for a [[Blues Music Award]].  Further acclaim was afforded by the British magazine, ''Blues Connection'', who named him "the new slide king of the National steel guitar."<ref name="AMG"/>

''Cherry Ball'' (1993) saw ''[[Dirty Linen]]'''s James Jensen state "Catfish will give you goose bumps and leave you howling for more!"  A further Blues Music Award nomination was generated by the release of ''Fresh Catfish'' in 1995.<ref name="AMG"/>

After ''Twist It Babe!'', his next release was ''Pony Run'' (1999).<ref name="AMG"/> ''Sweet Pea'' (2005) was praised by ''[[Living Blues]]'' who opined "the guitar playing is surely the main attraction here, and "Blotted Out My Mind" alone earns Catfish comparison to [[Frank Hovington]], [[Elizabeth Cotten]], and other virtuoso six-stringers."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.catfishkeith.com/sweetpeareviews.htm |title=Sweet Pea Reviews |publisher=Catfishkeith.com |date= |accessdate=2012-12-08}}</ref>

In 2008, Keith was inducted into the Iowa Blues Hall of Fame.<ref name="Cluny">{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.thecluny.com/listing/catfish-keith-cluny-2-0 |title=Tenth Anniversary Weekender: Catfish Keith (Cluny 2) |publisher=The Cluny |date= |accessdate=2012-12-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Hotle |first=David |url=http://www.catfishkeith.com/iowablueshalloffamearticle.htm |title=Catfish Inducted into Iowa Blues Hall of Fame |publisher=Catfishkeith.com |date= |accessdate=2012-12-08}}</ref>

He is an endorser of [[National Reso-Phonic Guitars]].<ref name="Cluny"/> Catfish Keith has issued an instructional DVD entitled ''Dynamic Country Blues Guitar''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.homespuntapes.com/Instructors/catfish-keith |title=Catfish Keith |publisher=Homespuntapes.com |date= |accessdate=2012-12-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.catfishkeith.com/guitarplayervideoreview.htm |title=guitarplayervideoreview |publisher=Catfishkeith.com |date= |accessdate=2012-12-08}}</ref>
